resolution: Resolved: Social media does more harm than good

speeches.content: Honorable judges, esteemed opponents, We stand before you today to affirm the resoluti on: Social media does more harm than good. While social media platforms promise connectivity and informati on, their pervasive negative impacts on mental health, democratic processes, and privacy undeniably outweigh any perceived benefits. Our first contention is the detrimental effect of social media on mental health, particularly among adolescents. Numerous studies corroborate this link. A 2018 study by the Pew Research Center found that 70% of teens view anxiety and depression as major problems among their peers, with social media often cited as a contributing fact or. The constant exposure to curated, idealized lives fosters social comparis on, leading to feelings of inadequacy, low self-esteem, and body image issues. Cyberbullying, a rampant problem on these platforms, further exacerbates these psychological harms, leaving lasting emotional scars. The dopamine-driven feedback loops inherent in social media design are intentionally addictive, leading to excessive use and withdrawal symptoms, effectively creating a behavioral addiction that displaces healthier activities and sleep. Secondly, social media actively undermines democratic processes and fuels societal divisi on. The algorithmic amplification of misinformation and disinformation is a well-documented phenomen on. Foreign adversaries and domestic bad actors exploit these platforms to spread propaganda, manipulate public opini on, and sow discord. The filter bubbles and echo chambers created by personalized algorithms reinforce existing biases, preventing exposure to diverse perspectives and hindering productive discourse. This polarization is not a byproduct; it is an inherent feature of platforms designed to maximize engagement, often at the expense of truth and unity. The Cambridge Analytica scandal vividly illustrates how user data can be weaponized to influence elections, demonstrating a clear threat to informed democratic participati on. Finally, social media platforms pose a severe threat to individual privacy. Users are constantly tracked, their data harvested

Honorable judges, esteemed opponents, We stand in firm opposition to the resoluti on. Social media, when properly understood, does more good than harm through democratizing informati on, enabling global connectivity, and empowering marginalized communities. During the COVID-19 pandemic, social media enabled remote learning for students globally. Khan Academy reaches millions through social platforms, offering quality education regardless of economic status. This unprecedented access to knowledge fundamentally outweighs concerns about misuse. Second, social media enables vital social movements and amplifies marginalized voices. The Arab Spring, Black Lives Matter, and Me Too movements gained momentum through social platforms, giving voice to those traditionally excluded from mainstream discourse. Without social media, these critical conversations about justice and equality would remain suppressed. A 2020 Pew study found 69% of Americans believe social media helps give voice to underrepresented groups. Third, social media creates economic opportunities and innovati on. Small businesses reach global markets without expensive advertising. Entrepreneurs build careers as content creators. The creator economy now supports millions of jobs that didn't exist before social media. Regarding our opponents' mental health argument: correlation does not equal causati on. Teen anxiety has multiple causes including academic pressure and economic uncertainty. Honorable judges, Our opponents argue that social media democratizes information and educati on. However, this access often comes with a severe cost: the proliferation of misinformati on. We contend that while these platforms can initiate conversati on, they frequently fail to sustain meaningful, organized acti on, often devolving into performative activism or exacerbating internal divisions. Regarding mental health, our opponents dismiss the link by claiming "correlation does not equal causati on" and citing a single Oxford study. This ignores the overwhelming body of research, including the Pew Research Center, demonstrating significant negative impacts.
